H0.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Ashoka the Great

H1.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Hammurabi

H2.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Aristotle

H3.text: who wrote the first declaration of human rights. Cyrus

A4.text: The United Nations has declared the relic to be an 'ancient declaration of human rights' since 1971, approved by then Secretary General Sithu U Thant, after he 'was given a replica by the sister of the Shah of Iran'.

A5.text: This view has been disputed by some as 'rather anachronistic' and tendentious, as the modern concept of human rights would have been quite alien to Cyrus's contemporaries and is not mentioned by the cylinder.

A6.text: The Cyrus Cylinder was dubbed the 'first declaration of human rights' by the pre-Revolution Iranian government.

A7.text: The essential character of the Cyrus Cylinder is not a general declaration of human rights or religious toleration but simply a building inscription, in the Babylonian and Assyrian tradition, commemorating Cyrus's restoration of the city of Babylon and the worship of Marduk previously neglected by Nabonidus.

A8.text: James Henry Breasted noted the Code's 'justice to the widow, the orphan, and the poor'.

A9.text: The Code's establishment on public stelae was supposedly intended to increase access to justice.
